data.title: Microsoft Gives Up on Book Search
data.meta_description: Microsoft said today it plans to phase out its book scanning effort, an initiative launched less than three years ago. "Today we informed our partners that we are ending the Live Search Books and Live Search Academic projects and that both sites will be taken down next week," wrote Satya Nadella, a senior vice president […]
data.text:
Microsoft said today it plans to phase out its book scanning effort, an initiative launched less than three years ago.

"Today we informed our partners that we are ending the Live Search Books and Live Search Academic projects and that both sites will be taken down next week," wrote Satya Nadella, a senior vice president at Microsoft, in a matter-of-fact blog post.

By most accounts, Microsoft's book-digitizing initiative was a me-too response to Google's effort, which began in 2004.

The reason for pulling the plug? There isn't any money to be made from such a nerdy pursuit. In their words:

"[W]e believe the next generation of search is about the development of an underlying, sustainable business model for the search engine, consumer, and content partner. For example, this past Wednesday we announced our strategy to focus on verticals with high commercial intent, such as travel, and offer users cash back on their purchases from our advertisers," Nadella wrote.

All told, Microsoft scanned 750,000 books and 80 million journal articles. The company says it will provide publishers with the digital versions of the books it scanned, and it encourages libraries to "build on the platform . . . to create digital archives available to library users and search engines."

Photo: Flickr/0olong

Nearly a year after the US government took Google to trial, a judge has found that the tech giant violated antitrust laws. A new trial will determine how Google should be penalized.
